It seems like "required-resources" help should say instead "Confirm resource availability before building". Is this correct?

Hi Aviel, Right but that's just a code.

In this case we are writing documentation to explain what this option does. Put yourself in the shoes of someone reading this documentation for the first time and trying to understand what each option does.

I think the help text from the screenshot is more helpful to the reader than "whether cachet is enabled". My understanding is that enabling the checkbox causes cachet to confirm that the listed resources are available before starting the build.  Confirm availability of listed resources before building. Requires the list of **resources** to also be defined. (default true)

IMO this makes the option much more clear about what it does as it explains that not only do you have to enable the checkbox, you have to also provide a list of resources for the option to work.

placement/tests/unit/base.py.message:
Is the intent simply that invoking ensure() under this fixture will return a MagicMock? If so, this will work, but it's a bit circuitous. What you're doing by using MonkeyPatch is replacing the ensure method with the result of the second argument, i.e. the result of invoking mock.MagicMock(), which is a (different) MagicMock. Then when ensure() is invoked, it's invoking that (second) MagicMock - which will return yet a third MagicMock.

If you instead use MockPatch with return_value=mock.MagicMock(), you'll only create the one MagicMock that'll be returned when you invoke ensure().

For that matter, you don't need MagicMock, as it's just a superset of Mock that has default magic methods, none of which you need. So you could just say:

 self.useFixture(fixtures.MockPatch('placement...ensure'))

(You'll get a regular Mock return_value by default)

Ah, thanks for the lesson. My awareness of the magic of mock is limited as mocks give me even more hives than returns within for loops.

I'll fix this up.

networking_ovn/common/ovn_client.py.message:
For this bug: https://launchpad.net/bugs/1833820
The original code need gets the lrouter_nat_name and set a new value. But the 'update_fip' has a '_delete_fip', it causes the lrouter_nat_name be lost, so update operator failed.
Now, you have modified the method '_create_or_update_floatingip' and it works as we expected. However, the 'update_fip' method also confused me, see below:

Why we should '_delete_fip' and then '_update_fip'?
IMO, first, '_update_fip' is enough, OVN could update a new value for NAT.

Second, '_delete_fip' and '_update_fip' are two transaction, why we put it together?

Thanks Li for taking a look.

For the 1st question:
There's a strong reference in the OVN NB schema in the LR table for the NAT entries [0]. This means, you cannot move a NAT entry from one router to assign it to another one. If you remove the NAT entry from a Logical Router, this NAT entry will go away from the NAT table. Hence, you'd need to recreate.

This is maybe something that we don't need to do all the time but only when moving a FIP to a different port, which is the bug that this patch is addressing. As this port can be in a network that is connected to a different router, we'll need to delete, then update (actually create :).

For the 2nd question:
The reason for having everything under the same transaction is that this comes all from a single API call (updating a FIP). We map Neutron objects (FIP) to OVN objects (NAT) and we use revision numbers to ensure consistency.
Sometimes, updating an OVN object requires different commands to the OVN NB database but we consolidate all those commands into a single transaction to make sure that the OVN state reflects the desired state in Neutron. If one single command fails, then the whole transaction will fail and we won't bump the revision number, hence creating an inconsistency that will be later fixed by the periodic maintenance task. More on this at [1].

I hope it helps :)

[0] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/v2.11.0/ovn/ovn-nb.ovsschema#L248
[1] https://docs.openstack.org/networking-ovn/latest/contributor/design/database_consistency.html

Get it. It's very clear.

Thanks Daniel for explaining it.

keystonemiddleware/auth_token/__init__.p.message: That is annoying. This would be a lot easier to read/maintain without the need to convert to regex.

Looking at a contrived example '/xxxx/{project_id}/yyyy'

Do we really want to go to a *? This seems to be a broken substitution, wouldn't this become /xxxx/*/yyyy, which would mean:

/xxxx matches the characters /xxxx literally (case sensitive)

/* matches the character / literally (case sensitive)
* Quantifier — Matches between zero and unlimited times, as many times as possible, giving back as needed (greedy)

/yyyy matches the characters /yyyy literally (case sensitive)


Now in the case of '/v1/servers/{server_id}': 

/v1/servers matches the characters /v1/servers literally (case sensitive)

/* matches the character / literally (case sensitive)
* Quantifier — Matches between zero and unlimited times, as many times as possible, giving back as needed (greedy)


This means we would match:
/v1/servers
/v1/servers/
/v1/servers//////////
/v1/servers/xxxxxxx
/v1/servers///////xxxxxx

Is this intended to allow for the first 3?

This stage is just meant to convert the {tag} syntax, which is a convenience for readability, to *, which has equivalent meaning from the user's point of view. So at the end of this stage, path_pattern will be a string (not a regex) that would behave as if the user had actually used a glob-style * rather than the tag-style {tag}. It's just normalizing the string for the next stage, where * and ** are actually converted to a regex format.

In your example, if we have /v1/servers/{server_id}, at the end of line 530 we have path_regex (now I see it is badly named) containing /v1/servers/*, and is just a string, ready to be further processed in the next few stages which will convert the string '*' to the regex /.*/.
I see what you mean now, I think it should not be allowed to make a request /v1//xxxx that omits the component named by the tag, and have incorporated this into the next patchset.

.* vs .+ on a tag replacement.

The question of 0 or more matching vs 1 or more matching:

use of 0 or more (*) means you can omit the tag, so making the replacement of * with [^\/]* means that /v1/{project_id}/XXXX allows for /v1//xxxxx and /v1/1234/xxxx

in the case of /v1/servers/{server_id}, * would allow for 
/v1/servers// which is semantically the same in HTTP land as /v1/servers/ whereas [^\/]+ would require some value for ID in the tag.

Tokenizing this would ultimately solve much of the same thing as long as that issue is still addressed if we care about it.

I'm not sure I understand the question. This is just processing the access rule in the app cred, it is not matching to a request yet. Let me try to convert this to a tokenizer and see if your concern is addressed.

Thanks for addressing the first concern, I see it now..., the question remains should we allow:

/v1/servers/
/v1/servers/////

Should we make it a "+" vs "*" (regex, 1 or more, vs 0 or more) for {tag}?

A couple comments here:

1) If we're doing this work, we can probably pre-compile the regex and then perform the sub, these are static regexes and since this happens a lot, it will be sped up. The compile should be done outside of the method (module level) and covers the regexes until line 542.

2) I'd like some explicit tests for this method. It's pretty hairy.

3) It might be easier to tokenize the glob, capturing the {tag} and ** as groups, then iterating through and replacing {tag} with [^\/]+ and ** with .* then reconstruct into a r'XXX' and run regex.match (see item 4 below, no need to compile)

4) The final regex doesn't need to be compiled explicitly, it could be run just with re.match(<pattern>, <string>).
This should probably be above the catalog checking. We don't care about the catalog in this case, we know we are identity and we know the path. Less work for high-traffic paths.

.match() used on line298 implies use of "^", this is in contrast to .search(). However, I am glad you're being explicit here (please do not take this as a comment that a change should be made).

    >>> x = 'ASdf'
    >>> re.match('df', x)
    >>> re.match('ASdf', x)
    <_sre.SRE_Match object; span=(0, 4), match='ASdf'>
    >>> re.match('ASdf', x)
So very much easier to follow. Thanks!

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
What should the scope of this be? Limited to a single account? Single container? Single object is definitely too narrow... I wonder if single container may also be... but at the same time, I could see us wanting to verify starting states from multiple versions...

Maybe we could have the setup/test parameterized? Like, take some label that would be used as a prefix for the containers we'll want to touch...

My plan for this initial patch was to start simple with a few CRUD tests. Overtime I'd expect us to add tests for features that have been available for a "long time" (I'm thinking of usual suspects: copy, versions, slo, dlo, etc)

Thoughts?

I wonder if it might be better to split between setup/check/teardown rather than before/after...

I could see someone wanting to test one particular upgrade, for example, and thus wanting some way to clean up afterwards.

I could also wee someone wanting to test a bunch of versions, though... piggybacking off the parameterized-testing idea, something like

 # start from swift version X
 setup('test-data-X')
 check('test-data-X') # sanity
 upgrade-to-Y()
 check('test-data-X')
 setup('test-data-Y')
 check('test-data-Y') # sanity
 upgrade-to-Z()
 check('test-data-X')
 check('test-data-Y')

yep, i've renamed to 'stage' and 'verify' for now, but I'm open to other ideas. 

I stayed away from 'setup' because it can be confusing since setup is already used in python unittest to mean something else.

Regarding the idea of testing multiple upgrades, that's an interesting idea, but i'd like to keep the scope small for now and we can add complexity in future patches. wdyt?

Will we have any expectation that new rolling upgrade tests will work with upgrades between old versions? For example, if I wrote a new test tomorrow, would a reviewer be justified in -1'ing it because it didn't pass during a ocata->pike upgrade?

I think the answer here is: "it depends". 

The idea of the tests is to inform us that our guarantee that one can upgrade swift from any "older" version to any "newer" version is true. 

If a test was written with the expectation that it should pass on a upgrade from ocata to pike then we should at least try to understand why it wasn't passing.

It might be that some of the tests might start adding not only support to check /info to check on enabled middleware but also versions to check on expected API support.

tox.ini.message:
Why is py36 being removed?

Also, I'm wondering if "py3" should be used here instead so that the default py3 interpreter will be used, as available on the test host.

Thanks Sean. I was trying to find any previous discussion for context... py37 isn't available by default in the LTS versions of the popular distros that developers use; but py36 is... So, a bit wonky to slide in a default; sure devs can use "tox -epy3" or "tox -epy36" to run python3 tests alone...

There have been various discussion on this, but basically, no need to require developers to have both py36 and py37 installed to be able to run local default tests. They can always run py36 if they want to, but it doesn't make much sense making both of them the default for local tox runs.

The variable value has been written in L138, you don't need to define a default value. This could be:
  -p $MYSQL_PASSWORD
Changed it to the variable instead. (The no empty space between the -p and the $ is needed to prevent the script from prompting the user to type in a password.)

what if there is no MYSQL_PASSWORD defined? It will then end up with something like

    /usr/bin/mysql -u root -p"" < $tmp_dir/mysql.sql

which will not work properly if access is available without password.
ok, it looks that indeed L138 prevents to have empty string here so it should be ok

From my understanding the bug might be due to the MYSQL version 5.7. (but I may be wrong) In that version a random root password is generated as opposed to having no password like in the previous versions. 
The MYSQL_PASSWORD is defined in this script on line 138 which overwrites the randomly generated one.

To answer your question - the "access being available without password" issue wouldn't occur in the version I'm using (5.7) but I'm not sure about the other ones.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo-container-.message: It doesn't check presence of docker-py, it's independent thing

guessing it is for that http://logs.openstack.org/96/670796/2/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-upgrade/fefea6f/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/standalone_upgrade.log.txt.gz#_2019-07-16_12_50_09 

cos there is no docker-py 
*similar to that we had it a while ago https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1824301
Why do we need to check if it exists? "state: absent" is idempotent in docker

Even though the docker_container module is idempotent, it requires to have python2-docker installed to work properly and the rpm is missing in our master environments. That's mostly the reason why it's failing...The docker binary is present but it's python-docker what's missing and we end up getting the error:
"Failed to import docker or docker-py (Docker SDK for Python) - No module named docker. Try `pip install docker` or `pip install docker-py` (Python 2.6)."

So, this is the best guard possible to avoid this bug...or we could change it into a check for the python2-docker rpm similar to the one we used to have in tripleo-docker-rm https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655511/1/roles/tripleo-docker-rm/tasks/main.yaml@2 which has been lost in the migration to tripleo-container-rm.

neutron/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall.message:
What you are doing here is drilling a hole in the firewall just for an specific protocol, instead of adding this rule in the Neutron Security Group (SG).

If the rule is marked with mark=1, that means the flow is hitting this rule [1]. If, as you commented in the bug description, you have a SG rule to allow this egress traffic, this rule should be in the same table (RULES_EGRESS_TABLE=72), with a priority of >=70 (greater than 40, which is the reject rule default priority).

But in the bug description you are talking about the following rule:
cookie=0x8bbcb4f28e827fee, duration=81.097s, table=82, n_packets=2, n_bytes=158, idle_age=1, priority=40,ct_state=+est,ip,reg5=0x23 actions=ct(commit,zone=NXM_NX_REG6[0..15],exec(load:0x1->NXM_NX_CT_MARK[]))

This is, as you can see in the table number (RULES_INGRESS_TABLE=82), an ingress rule. Same as before, you should review the rules applied in this ingress table according to your SG rule definition. You should have a rule with priority >=70.

Another comment about this rule. The default action should not be "normal", but a resubmit to the corresponding processing table.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/dec5eed17f9c74b945f2b8b3136854746deb10ee/neutron/agent/linux/openvswitch_firewall/firewall.py#L970

- "_deleted_ports" is a set to avoid port duplications. If a port has been deleted previously, any call to "add_to_deleted_ports" won't have any effect
- I have a second variable to have an timestamp ordered list. This can duplicate the memory used, but speeds up the logic.

Currently I'm not applying this logic. I'll update the patch and I'll add a test for this.

kubernetes/applications/stx-openstack/st.message: Can we reduce this to 5 minutes. Based on my observed vbox testing behavior this needs ~1.5 minutes to complete the jobs. H/W should be faster.

For normal case, it should be no difference. 1800s should be safer.
For fail case, 5 minutes will make the failure quicker.
Currently, most charts use 1800s as the timeout value.

If we think the timeout should be adjusted, I prefer to create another story to review all the timeout values, and adjust them based on the time consumed in apply.log.
Is it ok?
I'd change this now since we are updating the section of the manifest.

It's not clear to me why these completed pods/jobs are being removed from the standby controller, but this could potentially be a problem on AIO-SX. 

The proposed change requires at least one completed pod/job is still present in the cluster. If all 3 are scheduled to the standby controller, and the swact/lock/unlock occurs, then none will remain. I think this will still trigger the timeout in this case. 

It may be better to change this to:


  resources: []


This way we don't wait for anything. Since we are just running some jobs to completion to set up endpoints, I don't see an immediate need to wait for this.

When host reboot, the job will not be cleared, but the pod created for the job will be cleared, since it is in complete status, there is no reason to keep the pod when host reboot.
For both 1st and re-apply case, we should wait job be in complete/ready status to ensure the chart is applied successfully.
For ceph-rgw chart, there is only job task, so we should wait for job only, not for pod.

You should not delete the job manually. To trigger the re-apply, you need delete the chart in helm.
For your case, ceph_rgw shows deployed status in helm, and there is no update for the chart, so armada will not re-schedule the job, and cause the timeout. The manual delete cause the status mis-match between armada/helm and k8s. If you think it is an issue we need fix, I prefer to open another LP to cover it. Is it ok?
We don't need another LP. I'll take care of this with an LP I have opened.
Remove all 3 pods/jobs and then reapply the application. It will still timeout. The proposed fix doesn't cover all possible re-apply scenarios.

cinder/volume/drivers/hpe/hpe_3par_commo.message: I think this comment may go with some code below?
The "on host %(host_name)s" part of this is misleading, because you're logging the host that owns the volume, not the host where the instances are.
This doesn't seem right to just not do anything if there are multiple attachments.

terminate_connection() gets called when there is a detach. Here we are removing the luns and host entry from 3par and we want to do this only when there is only 1 instance attached to the volume.

Similar logic is applied here:
https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/powermax/common.py#L699
https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/volume/drivers/nexenta/ns5/iscsi.py#L317

Is it possible that multiple terminate_connection calls happen at once, and then the connection is never terminated?

(i.e. does this whole section need a lock around it?)

Hi Eric,

Based on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/424454/ we are not handling race conditions.
The root of the concern about the race condition is that this can be true for both terminate_connection calls depending on timing.
This also races if another initialize_connection() call happened, adding an attachment, while this method is running.

cinder/volume/drivers/hpe/hpe_3par_iscsi.message:
f_name is not appropriate here because the lock should apply between initialize_connection and terminate_connection.  Just using
    '3par-{volume.id}'
should do it.
